title: Configure Service Management security
content:
Protect Service Management from malicious software

External data such as archive, image, and binary files may contain software intentionally designed to cause damage to your system. In Service Management, possible input channels include:

  • File upload from any requests in Service Portal
  • File upload from any supported records in Agent Interface
  • File importing through entity data import, knowledge import, and translation file import
  • Document exchange with REST calls
Every time before any external data is input into Service Management, we strongly recommend that you scan for suspicious/malicious files to protect the system from malware attacks.

Protect Service Management using Web Application Firewall (WAF) rules

The Hardening Service Management Automation X with WAF document is available on the Software Support Portal. This document provides information about how to use WAF rule sets to harden a Service Management environment and protect it from external malicious access. To download this document, you must log on to the Software Support Portal and your account must be configured to contain a valid Service Agreement ID (SAID).

Prevent host header injection attacks

If you are using default and custom domains in suite of products such as Service Management, Cloud Management, Asset Management, or Audit, set up firewall rules for custom domain hosts. This helps prevent host header injection attacks. Refer to the following sample scenario to set up the firewall rules using AWS Application LoadBalancer (ALB).  You can apply similar configurations with other cloud providers.

Use ALB's Listeners Rules feature to control the traffic based on the Host header value and enhance the security for your applications. For example, you can block unauthorized domains or attackers by setting up listener rules to check the Host header value and allow requests to specific hosts only. Also, since the traffic is filtered at the ALB layer, the load on the application layer is reduced, resulting in improved performance.

The following steps are for setting up Host header listener rule on ALB.

  1. Go to the Amazon EC2 console.
  2. On the left-hand navigation pane, scroll down to Load Balancing, and click Load balancers.

You will find all the configured load balancers listed here.

Select the ALB and the listener

  1. Find and select the ALB on which to add the Host header rule.
  2. Go to the Listeners Tab.
  3. From the list of listeners, select the listener (HTTPS) to which to add the rule.

If you do not have a listener, create one.

Edit or add a listener rule

  1. Click the View/edit rules link of the HTTPS listener you selected.
  2. If you have already created any rules, click the Edit button to modify the rule.

If you have not created any rules, use the Add option to create one.

Add a Host header condition and action

  1. Click + Add condition to add a condition for the Host header.
  2. Choose Host header from the dropdown.
  3. In the Host field, enter the domain name you want to match. For example, www.example.com. You can add up to 5 domains.
  4. Configure the action that the ALB should take when the Host header conditions matches the Host header value in the incoming request. For example,
    • Forward: Direct the traffic to a specific target group.
  5. Click Save or Update to save the rule.

Test the rule

  1. Send a request where host header value matches the conditions in the listener rule. Make sure it is routed correctly. In the following example, the host header value Host: example.com matches the listener rule conditions, so the request is allowed. 
    curl -i https://example.com/bo -H "Host: example.com"

HTTP/1.1 200 Connection established
 
HTTP/2 200
date: Mon, 03 Mar 2025 10:39:45 GMT
content-type: text/html
content-length: 797
last-modified: Wed, 19 Feb 2025 02:10:39 GMT
pragma: no-cache
access-control-allow-origin: *
content-security-policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; connect-src 'self'; img-src * data: blob:; style-src * 'unsafe-inline'; frame-ancestors 'self'
 
<!doctype html>
...message body...
</html>
  2. Send a request where host header value does not match the conditions in the listener rule. Make sure the request is blocked. In the following example, the host header value Host: xyz.com does not matches the listener rule condition, so the request is blocked. 
    curl -i https://example.com/bo -H "Host: xyz.com"
HTTP/1.1 200 Connection established
 
HTTP/2 401
server: awselb/2.0
date: Mon, 03 Mar 2025 10:40:04 GMT
content-type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
content-length: 9
 
Not Found

Request throttling in ESM RESTful APIs

When the load of requests coming to the ESM system is not regulated, it could lead to slow responses, performance degradation, and even downtime. To prevent this, you can enable the throttling feature on ESM RESTful APIs. When you enable request throttling for an API, the number requests a client can make to a specific tenant’s resources within a set timeframe is limited. For example, you can set a throttling rule to limit the number of times a SMA service portal user on IP address 124.76.3.8 can request for a service within a span of one hour. 

Request throtlting is supported in all the ESM RESTful APIs that fall under the following patterns:

  • /rest/{tenantId}/.*
  • /xie/v1/namespace/{tenantId}/.*
  • /auth/authentication-endpoint/authenticate/token

Request throttle tiers and categories

Tiers

The throttling required for different tenants in a farm may vary depending on their priority and size. To address this, the tenant are catagoriezed into three tiers - Basic, Medium, and Advanced. Each tier offers a different request throttling limit for the tenants, with the Basic tier having the strictest rate limits. The default tier is Advanced where there is no throttling, and the requests are not regulated.

Request categories

In each tier, there are two request categories for distinguishing normal requests and integration requests. Normal requests includes requests from end users such as, SMA portal users and agent users accessing the application from their browsers. Integration requests includes all requests other than the Normal request.

Tier-wise configurations

Suite administrators can customize the throttle settings to apply stricter rules.

The following example shows the throttle settings for Basic tier:

# The list of tenant that with the strictest Restful api throttling, format is: "<tenantID>|<tenantID>"
basicTenants: ""
# The RPS settings for normal requests (portal and agent) of the basic tier
basicTenantRPS: "10r/s"
basicTenantRPSBurst: "100 delay=50"
# The RPS settings for integration requests (all requests other than from browser) of the basic tier
basicTenantRPSBots: "3r/s"
basicTenantRPSBurstBots: "10 delay=5"

The following example shows the throttle settings for Medium tier:

# The list of tenant that with the moderate Restful api throttling, format is: "<tenantID>|<tenantID>"
mediumTenants: ""
# The RPS settings for normal requests (portal and agent) of the medium tier
mediumTenantRPS: "1000r/s"
mediumTenantRPSBurst: "1000 nodelay"
# The RPS settings for integration requests (all requests other than from browser) of the medium tier
mediumTenantRPSBots: "50r/s"
mediumTenantRPSBurstBots: "100 nodelay"

The following example shows the throttle settings for Advanced tier:

# The RPS settings for normal requests (portal and agent) of the advanced tier
advancedTenantRPS: "4000r/s"
advancedTenantRPSBurst: "4000 nodelay"
# The RPS settings for integration requests (all requests other than from browser) of the advanced tier
advancedTenantRPSBots: "4000r/s"
advancedTenantRPSBurstBots: "4000 nodelay"

Change a tenant's tier

By default all tenants belong to the Advanced tier. You may want to switch tenants to a different tier such as Medium or Basic to apply stricter throttling rules. The following examples show how to switch the tenant 100000003 to the Basic tier:

  1. Run the following command to get the current values: 
    helm get values <release> -n <namespace> > values.yaml
  2. Append the following snippet to the values.yaml file: 
    nginx:
  configmap:
    nginx:
      basicTenants:"<existing tenant ids>|100000003"
  3. Run the following command to apply the change: 
    helm upgrade <release> <helm-chart-package> -n <namespace> -f values.yaml

Update request throttle settings of Tenant tier

The following example illustrates how to set the Integration Request throttling of the Basic tier:

  1. Run the following command to get the current values: 
     helm get values <release> -n <namespace> > values.yaml
  2. Append the following snippet to the values.yaml file to set the throttle to two requests per second (2r/s): 
    nginx:
  configmap:
    nginx:
       basicTenantRPSBots: "2r/s"  // Refer to nginx limit_req_zone doc for the usage 
      basicTenantRPSBurstBots: "5" // Refer to nginx limit_req doc for the usage
    In this configuration, the setting basicTenantRPSBots=2r/s indicates that the throttle limit is set to 2 requests per second for one instance of the deployment. The overall throttle limit is a product of throttle limt per instance and the number of replicas. For example, in a system that has 3 replicas of itom-ingress-controller and a throttle limit set to basicTenantRPSBots=2r/s, the overall_throttle_limit = no_of_replicas * throttle_limit_per_instance = 3 * 2 = 6r/s.
  3. Run the following command to apply the change: 
    helm upgrade <release> <helm-chart-package> -n <namespace> -f values.yaml

AllowList configurations

You may want to exempt certain IP address from throttling. For example, the IP addresses of ESM pods running inside the Kubernetes cluster. You can add such IP addresses to the allowList to prevent throttling. Requests from IP address in the allowList will not be throttled irrespective of the tenants it may accesses. The following example shows how to add an IP address to the allowList:

You must always add the IP CIDR of ESM Pods to the  allowList, which can exampt all ESM internal requests from throttling. You can get the IP CIDR of ESM pods from your cluster admin.
  1. Run the following command to get the current values: 
     helm get values <release> -n <namespace> > values.yaml
  2. Append the following snippet to the values.yaml file to add IP address to the allowList: 
    nginx:
  configmap:
    nginx:
       allowList: ["<Existing IP>", "<New IP or IP CIDR>"]
  3. Run the following command to apply the change: 
    helm upgrade <release> <helm-chart-package> -n <namespace> -f values.yaml

Content Security Policy

By defining the appropriate Content Security Policy (CSP) directives in the response header, you can determine which data sources are allowed to load by your web application. The CSP directives defines trusted sources for content such as scripts, styles, and images. After configuring a policy, content loaded from untrusted sources will be blocked by your browser.

To configure the CSP directives, perform the following steps::

  1. Log in to Service Management.
  2. Go to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings > Content Security Policy.
  3. Click Configure.
  4. Configure the CSP directives as required.
    To add or remove a CSP item, click + Add item or Remove. 
    Note: When you select Remove, all user-defined values will be lost and the Service Management default value will be used. 
    You may implement the following CSP directives for your environment. When configuring the source values for the CSP directives, you may add one or multiple allowed domains, separated by space characters.
    CSP directive Definition SMA default value User-defined values Notes

    default-src 

    The HTTP Content-Security-Policy (CSP) default-src directive serves as a fallback for the other CSP fetch directives. For each of the following directives that are absent, the user agent looks for the default-src directive and uses this value for it: 

    child-src 

    connect-src 

    font-src 

    frame-src 

    img-src 

    manifest-src 

    media-src 

    object-src 

    prefetch-src 

    script-src 

    script-src-elem 

    script-src-attr 

    style-src 

    style-src-elem 

    style-src-attr 

    worker-src 

    'self' 

    'self' <UserDefinedValue>

    Example:
    ‘self’ example.com

    'self' will always be automatically applied in addition to your setting value.

    connect-src 

    The HTTP Content-Security-Policy (CSP) connect-src directive restricts the URLs which can be loaded using script interfaces. The APIs that are restricted are:

    <a> ping, 

    fetch(), 

    XMLHttpRequest, 

    WebSocket, 

    EventSource

    Navigator.sendBeacon(). 

    * 

    'self' <UserDefinedValue>

    Example:
    'self' example1.com example2.com

    If the translation tool is enabled, the URL of the translation vendor will be added to 'connect-src' automatically. 

    'self' will always be automatically applied in addition to your setting value.

    img-src 

    The HTTP Content-Security-Policy img-src directive specifies valid sources of images and favicons. 

    * data: blob: 

    'self' <UserDefinedValue> data: blob: 

    Example:
    'self' example.com data: blob: 

    The system can't work without the 'data:' and 'blob:' source values. These two values are always added to 'img-src' automatically. 

    'self' will always be automatically applied in addition to your setting value.

    style-src 

    The HTTP Content-Security-Policy (CSP) style-src directive specifies valid sources for stylesheets. 

    * 'unsafe-inline' 

    'self' <UserDefinedValue> 'unsafe-inline' 

    Example:
    'self' example.com 'unsafe-inline' 

    The system can't work without the 'unsafe-line' source value. 'unsafe-line' is always added to 'style-src' automatically. 

    'self' will always be automatically applied in addition to your setting value 

    script-src 

    The HTTP Content-Security-Policy (CSP) script-src directive specifies valid sources for JavaScript. This includes not only URLs loaded directly into
